posts.name: Jaco Xia

image 758×624 145 KB

image 758×624 145 KB

image 758×624 145 KB

I’ve read a bit about the adder for 25 chain (.018"), but was wondering that for shorter center to center distances (in this case, I calculated the c-c to be 3.605" for a 71 link chain), would I use a smaller adder? I read on another post that they typically use half the adder for c-c distances less than 3", but here there’s a lot more wrap on the sprockets and I’m not sure if it’s smart to use half the adder.

posts.name: Andrew Torrance
posts.cooked:
The chain adder that we used to do on our west-coast-drives back in the day was always determined through experimentation for the specific center center we were trying to achieve. It really isn’t about it being a fixed length and its more of a percentage thing, with long chain runs needing more extra center-center added. Also, even with the CC add it still won’t be a very tensioned chain, which is probably fine for a drivebase wheel since you have an encoder on the output wheel anyway, but is bad for something like a wrist/arm/intake-deploy pivot.

Looking at your sketch, I’d highly encourage you to find a way to add an adjustable tensioner. Here are some options:

Split pinion and output into two plates that you can slide apart from each. Could use a snail Cam to push plates apart and ensure cannot slip / come loose.

Add a back-bend idler sprocket/roller that pushes on the chain path, ideally a backbend so that you increase the amount of wrap on your pinion.

Add an inline chain tensioner , this only works if tensioner won’t go over the sprockets, which looks unlikely for your application. The span between sprockets must be long enough and/or the angular range of motion low enough so the tensioner doesnt try to wrap around a sprocket.

See slides from @Travis_Schuh ’s presentation for some pictures and ideas.

posts.name: Jaco Xia
posts.cooked: Do you think using an idler sprocket on a slot would suffice? or would it probably loosen quickly / not tension the chain that well?

posts.name: Andrew Torrance
posts.cooked:
That can definitely work, we did something similar with an idler belt on a slot on our 2024 elevator. Using a nylock locknut let us make sure it was very tight (no worry of stripping aluminum threads or lack of loctite).

image 768×1000 134 KB

posts.name: Skye Leake
posts.cooked:
Edit: I wrote this as a draft before @Torrance replied, and then came back to it and posted.

This depends so much on how it is implemented.

Idler sprockets on cantilevered dead axles (where the dead axle slides in a slot and is tightened down) can work just fine, especially when used in conjunction with a snail cam.

However there are a few things that you can do to make this work in your favor as loads (dynamic and static) increase.

Do not place the slot in line with the loads - by this I mean: the force the idler sees when tensioned should not push along the axis of the slot. Use trigonometry to your advantage!

Do not place the slot in line with the loads - by this I mean: the force the idler sees when tensioned should not push along the axis of the slot. Use trigonometry to your advantage!

Use a cam to lock things in place (see above)

Use a cam to lock things in place (see above)

Use a large dead axle and a small idler - the idler acts as a lever on the cantilevered stub shaft, so in order for a small shaft to support the loads it needs to be small and short with a clean 90 degree surface.

Use a large dead axle and a small idler - the idler acts as a lever on the cantilevered stub shaft, so in order for a small shaft to support the loads it needs to be small and short with a clean 90 degree surface.

You can see much of this in the picture Torrance posted. There is a large flat surface on a short stub shaft. The forces on the idler are not trying to push the stub shaft directly down the slot.

posts.name: Jaco Xia
posts.cooked:
image 697×518 93.3 KB Thanks for the advice! I added the CAM and it is pressing against a bolt head that moves along a slot that holds the deadaxle for the idler sprocket. Is this sufficient? Would pressing against the bolt head fail? image 1045×760 92.4 KB

image 697×518 93.3 KB

image 697×518 93.3 KB

image 1045×760 92.4 KB

image 1045×760 92.4 KB

Edit: Oh actually, it is probably smarter to put the cam on the outside of the plate, and have the cam press against the hex shaft…

posts.name: Skye Leake
posts.cooked:
Looks good!

Make sure you have an access hole for the fastener to adjust things and tighten properly (looks like you are ok in this regard)

Ensure you have appropriate spacers and whatnot

Use a socket hap or hex head if you can as you can tighten them better due to the larger hex

Others may have opinions on using one fastener here or two for the standoff/spacer… I think I am leaning towards one as you are not relying on  pulling against aluminum threads in the standoff and it would be easier to keep things aligned.

edit:

jxia:

Edit: Oh actually, it is probably smarter to put the cam on the outside of the plate, and have the cam press against the hex shaft…

good call.
